summary:
Try these...your liver will thank you! 😉⠀
--⠀
The liver has many important functions. It removes harmful material from the...
caption:
Try these…your liver will thank you! 😉⠀
–⠀
The liver has many important functions. It removes harmful material from the bloodstream, and helps with digestion making it critical that you eat foods to help keep your liver healthy. ⠀
__⠀
These are our recommendations:⠀
–⠀
🔴Coffee: One of the best beverages you can drink to promote liver health! It lowers the risk of cirrhosis, and may help reduce risk of developing liver cancer. ⠀
🔴Grapefruit: Rich source of vitamin C, which helps the body turn toxins into substances that can be dissolved in water for easy removal. They also stimulate bile production to flush more toxins and excess fat from the system.⠀
🔴Nuts: Help the liver flush fat soluble toxins. They are also a good source of arginine, which the liver uses to remove ammonia, ⠀
glutathione, and many other toxins.⠀
🔴Tea: Helps improve blood markers of liver health, improve liver enzyme levels, shrink fat deposits in the liver, and may also reduce oxidative stress. Cranberries & Blueberries: These help protect the liver from damage, and may even improve its immune and antioxidant responses.⠀
–⠀
Make sure you’re following @MealPrepOnfleek #MPOFWhatToEat #MealPrepOnFleek @easymealpreprecipes⠀
__⠀
#mealprep #healthy #health #healthyeating #fitfam #cleaneating #eatclean #healthyfood #healthylifestyle #fit #diet #healthy #food #nutrition #nutritionfacts #healthyeating #healthychoices #lifestyle #digestive #digestivesystem #digestivehealth
https://www.instagram.com/p/Bn3pHGGAO04/?utm_source=ig_tumblr_share&igshid=wsb5l9a1b6ft

summary: Amen.
‘Eating for two’ during pregnancy is a dangerous myth, study suggests
title: ‘Eating for two’ during pregnancy is a dangerous myth, study suggests
body:
While it’s easy to believe that pregnancy warrants an extra slice of cake at tea time, the old adage that women can “eat for two” when they’re expecting poses health risks to the child and mother-to-be, new research suggests.

Published in the journal Diabetologia, the study shows that if a woman gains too much or too little weight during pregnancy, it can have adverse effects on their child.

According to the analysis of 905 mother-child pairs, which was conducted in Hong Kong, gaining too much weight could put your offspring at an increased risk of insulin resistance and high blood pressure.

The child may also be more predisposed to macrosomia, whereby a newborn is significantly larger than average.

Plus, they may have a higher than normal BMI - all of which researchers say could lead to further cardiometabolic risks down the line.

Participants’ weight gain was measured against the Institute of Medicine’s (IOM) guidelines and researchers found that pregnant women who’d gained more weight than the IOM recommended amount had children with higher blood pressure and poorer blood sugar control than those who gained weight within the recommended range.

Interestingly, the same adverse effects were true for women who actually gained less weight than the recommended amount.

On average, the weight change from pre-pregnancy to delivery was 15kg for women taking part in the study, with 41 per cent having gained weight exceeding the recommended range and 17 per cent having gained weight below, with those in the former group more likely to be young and have a higher BMI.

Meanwhile, 42 per cent gained weight within the recommended levels.

While lead researcher Professor Wing Hung Tam doesn’t think the results mean we should revert back to the practice of regular weigh-ins for pregnant women - which the NHS stopped doing in the early 1990s - he said it’s crucial to educate them about the implications of pregnancy weight gain and to dismiss the “eating for two” theory.

“What’s more important is that ‘eating for two’ could be harmful,” he tells The Independent.

“A pregnancy requires an extra 300 kcal per day. What a pregnant mother needs is a balanced diet meeting such requirements with adequate micronutrients.

“They also need to have moderate exercise to avoid putting up excessive weight gain.”

Though the study focused on highlighting the adverse effects that excess pregnancy weight gain can have on children, Hung Tam explains that it also poses a series of health risks to the mother, such as a higher risk of gestational diabetes mellitus - a condition where the mother has higher than normal glucose levels.

“These findings have important implications for both prevention and treatment,” the study’s authors conclude.

“There is a need for greater awareness and monitoring of weight gain during pregnancy.”

Published in the journal Diabetologia, the study shows that if a woman gains too much or too little weight during pregnancy, it can have adverse effects on their child.

The child may also be more predisposed to macrosomia, whereby a newborn is significantly larger than average.

Plus, they may have a higher than normal BMI - all of which researchers say could lead to further cardiometabolic risks down the line.

Participants’ weight gain was measured against the Institute of Medicine’s (IOM) guidelines and researchers found that pregnant women who’d gained more weight than the IOM recommended amount had children with higher blood pressure and poorer blood sugar control than those who gained weight within the recommended range.

Interestingly, the same adverse effects were true for women who actually gained less weight than the recommended amount.

On average, the weight change from pre-pregnancy to delivery was 15kg for women taking part in the study, with 41 per cent having gained weight exceeding the recommended range and 17 per cent having gained weight below, with those in the former group more likely to be young and have a higher BMI.

Meanwhile, 42 per cent gained weight within the recommended levels.

Though the study focused on highlighting the adverse effects that excess pregnancy weight gain can have on children, Hung Tam explains that it also poses a series of health risks to the mother, such as a higher risk of gestational diabetes mellitus - a condition where the mother has higher than normal glucose levels.

While it’s easy to believe that pregnancy warrants an extra slice of cake at tea time, the old adage that women can “eat for two” when they’re expecting poses health risks to the child and mother-to-be, new research suggests.

Published in the journal Diabetologia, the study shows that if a woman gains too much or too little weight during pregnancy, it can have adverse effects on their child.

According to the analysis of 905 mother-child pairs, which was conducted in Hong Kong, gaining too much weight could put your offspring at an increased risk of insulin resistance and high blood pressure.

The child may also be more predisposed to macrosomia, whereby a newborn is significantly larger than average.

Plus, they may have a higher than normal BMI - all of which researchers say could lead to further cardiometabolic risks down the line.

Participants’ weight gain was measured against the Institute of Medicine’s (IOM) guidelines and researchers found that pregnant women who’d gained more weight than the IOM recommended amount had children with higher blood pressure and poorer blood sugar control than those who gained weight within the recommended range.

Interestingly, the same adverse effects were true for women who actually gained less weight than the recommended amount.

On average, the weight change from pre-pregnancy to delivery was 15kg for women taking part in the study, with 41 per cent having gained weight exceeding the recommended range and 17 per cent having gained weight below, with those in the former group more likely to be young and have a higher BMI.

Meanwhile, 42 per cent gained weight within the recommended levels.

While lead researcher Professor Wing Hung Tam doesn’t think the results mean we should revert back to the practice of regular weigh-ins for pregnant women - which the NHS stopped doing in the early 1990s - he said it’s crucial to educate them about the implications of pregnancy weight gain and to dismiss the “eating for two” theory.

“A pregnancy requires an extra 300 kcal per day. What a pregnant mother needs is a balanced diet meeting such requirements with adequate micronutrients.

Though the study focused on highlighting the adverse effects that excess pregnancy weight gain can have on children, Hung Tam explains that it also poses a series of health risks to the mother, such as a higher risk of gestational diabetes mellitus - a condition where the mother has higher than normal glucose levels.

“These findings have important implications for both prevention and treatment,” the study’s authors conclude.

summary: Drinking water at the gym via /r/Fitness
title: Drinking water at the gym via /r/Fitness
body:
So I’ve been working out for about 6 months now. One thing I’ve noticed is I feel the need to drink way more water than anyone else I know who goes. Seriously I typically go through about 2l in a session. I know you are supposed to drink a lot of water to stay healthy, but should you be drinking this mush during exertion? I’m wondering if it could be related to the end session light headedness I sometimes experience . Any advice would be appreciated.



Submitted September 18, 2018 at 05:11AM by shaneacton
via reddit https://ift.tt/2QCNB4F

summary:

“ 40kg pistols  I was 12 years old the first time I did...
caption:
40kg pistols by the master @stevecotterikff ! Thanks for your share!
・・・
“ 40kg pistols I was 12 years old the first time I did a Crane Dip-the Kung Fu technique long before the terms “pistols” was made popular through the writing of Pavel Tsatsouline in his book Naked Warrior. Now, 36 years later, I still find it to be a challenging, practical application for every day life”#kettlebells #kettlebell #health #fitness

blog.name: geekymedguru
blog.title: a geek in white coat
blog.description:
A tech savvy doctor •
Med Blogger • avid reader • Global Citizen • 
" Whoever saves a life, it is as though he had saved all mankind "
 Our main purpose of this life is to serve Humanity by spreading love & peace ☮

summary: Need a cure-all? Get moving.
title: Need a cure-all? Get moving.
body:
Various studies have shown how exercise helps you avoid disease and look youthful. You don’t have to slog at the gym. Just walk every day.



An article by Hugo Saner in the Journal of Preventive Cardiology says exercise is medicine. I couldn’t agree more. If there is a single elixir of life, which guarantees good health and youthful looks, it is exercise, and not pills. It’s not that pills don’t help or are not effective; physical activity is simply a far better solution.

An article by Morris in The Lancet in 1953 opened a Pandora’s box on exercise. This study of London bus drivers and conductors found fewer cases of heart disease in mobile, middle-aged conductors compared to sedentary drivers. Several subsequent studies produced similar results. According to an estimate, each increase of 1Metabolic Equivalent for Task (MET), a measure of the amount of oxygen and calories used by the body during physical activity, leads to a 12 per cent improvement in survival.

Exercise has salubrious effects on many physiological causes responsible for heart disease. It releases endorphins, the so-called happy hormones, in the body, making one feel content and at peace. According to a study, smoking cessation can be achieved in about 20 per cent of patients who exercise compared to just 10 per cent of patients who are determined to quit the habit but don’t exercise. At the end of one year, 12 per cent of exercisers remained off smoking compared to 5 per cent of non-exercisers. Workouts increase the nitric oxide level of the body, which keeps the heart healthy, and there is evidence that improved levels help us look youthful. They reduce the activity of the sympathetic nervous system, thereby helping lower blood pressure.

There is a very positive response on the factors causing blood clots in the heart, and it could be achieved by even a single session of walking. Over 40 studies have assessed the value of exercise in blood pressure control, with an average reduction of 3.4 systolic and 2.4 diastolic pressure being observed. It doesn’t matter how often you work out in a week or how long or intense the session is — even light exercise can help you control BP. Physical activity is also known to release stem cells from the marrow, which repair the heart and its arteries.

According to a study in The Lancet, physical inactivity costs the global economy around $68 million a year in healthcare and productivity losses. It also states that if you exercise for 30 minutes, five days a week, you will save around $2,500 a year on medical bills.

For all you social drinkers on the cocktail circuit, exercise has certain benefits. A study by the University College London and the University of Sydney said that people who drank regularly and worked out for an hour daily had the same odds of dying as teetotallers. Physical activity counters the harmful effects of alcohol, even providing some protection from cancer and heart disease by reducing inflammation and harmful hormones. This is certainly heartening news. Alcohol consumption, even within the so-called recommended limits, is associated with 36 per cent higher risk of death from cancer and 13 per cent from other conditions and causes. But this risk can be lowered through 150 minutes of walking per week. This was reported in the British Journal of Sports Medicine. The author, however, clarified the workout recommendation should not be construed as a licence to drink more alcohol.

Some sedentary patients are reluctant to exercise, fearing it would lead to complications and even death. There is certainly some risk of a heart attack during intense training. The annual incidence of sudden cardiac death, which is exercise-related, is 5.4 per 1,00,000 deaths. The risk is 56 times higher for sedentary people and only 5 times higher for those who are physically active. It is unfortunate that this fact receives more attention in the press than the several benefits of physical activity.

It’s not necessary that you hit the gym every day or take up swimming or squash. Just walk half an hour daily. If you struggle initially, don’t worry. Multiple Olympic track champion Mo Farah did not run long distances on an impulse, he did it through rigorous training. Train yourself slowly. I promise you won’t regret it.

summary: Women should add these 5 Fruits in their Diet after 25 years
title: Women should add these 5 Fruits in their Diet after 25 years
body: Women should add these 5 Fruits in their Diet after 25 years. Advice for a healthy diet is the same for men and women: Eat more fruit, vegetables, whole grains, legumes and nuts. Limit sodium, sugar and saturated fat. Nutrient requirements change as we get older, in large part because of changing hormone levels. Aging can also affect whether you’re better off getting a certain nutrient from a supplement rather than food.

reblog.comment: Women should add these 5 Fruits in their Diet after 25 years. Advice for a healthy diet is the same for men and women: Eat more fruit, vegetables, whole grains, legumes and nuts. Limit sodium, sugar and saturated fat. Nutrient requirements change as we get older, in large part because of changing hormone levels. Aging can also affect whether you’re better off getting a certain nutrient from a supplement rather than food.

Aging can also affect whether you’re better off getting a certain nutrient from a supplement rather than food.
